articles.title: Quantum chips just proved they’re ready for the real world
articles.summary: Diraq has shown that its silicon-based quantum chips can maintain world-class accuracy even when mass-produced in semiconductor foundries. Achieving over 99% fidelity in two-qubit operations, the breakthrough clears a major hurdle toward utility-scale quantum computing. Silicon’s compatibility with existing chipmaking processes means building powerful quantum processors could become both cost-effective and scalable.
articles.content:
UNSW Sydney nano-tech startup Diraq has shown its quantum chips aren't just lab-perfect prototypes - they also hold up in real-world production, maintaining the 99% accuracy needed to make quantum computers viable.

Diraq, a pioneer of silicon-based quantum computing, achieved this feat by teaming up with European nanoelectronics institute Interuniversity Microelectronics Centre (imec). Together they demonstrated the chips worked just as reliably coming off a semiconductor chip fabrication line as they do in the experimental conditions of a research lab at UNSW.

UNSW Engineering Professor Andrew Dzurak, who is the founder and CEO of Diraq, said up until now it hadn't been proven that the processors' lab-based fidelity - meaning accuracy in the quantum computing world - could be translated to a manufacturing setting.

"Now it's clear that Diraq's chips are fully compatible with manufacturing processes that have been around for decades."

In a paper published on Sept. 24 in Nature, the teams report that Diraq-designed, imec-fabricated devices achieved over 99% fidelity in operations involving two quantum bits - or 'qubits'. The result is a crucial step towards Diraq's quantum processors achieving utility scale, the point at which a quantum computer's commercial value exceeds its operational cost. This is the key metric set out in the Quantum Benchmarking Initiative, a program run by the United States' Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) to gauge whether Diraq and 17 other companies can reach this goal.

Utility-scale quantum computers are expected to be able to solve problems that are out of reach of the most advanced high-performance computers available today. But breaching the utility-scale threshold requires storing and manipulating quantum information in millions of qubits to overcome the errors associated with the fragile quantum state.

"Achieving utility scale in quantum computing hinges on finding a commercially viable way to produce high-fidelity quantum bits at scale," said Prof. Dzurak.

"Diraq's collaboration with imec makes it clear that silicon-based quantum computers can be built by leveraging the mature semiconductor industry, which opens a cost-effective pathway to chips containing millions of qubits while still maximizing fidelity."

Silicon is emerging as the front-runner among materials being explored for quantum computers - it can pack millions of qubits onto a single chip and works seamlessly with today's trillion-dollar microchip industry, making use of the methods that put billions of transistors onto modern computer chips.

Diraq has previously shown that qubits fabricated in an academic laboratory can achieve high fidelity when performing two-qubit logic gates, the basic building block of future quantum computers. However, it was unclear whether this fidelity could be reproduced in qubits manufactured in a semiconductor foundry environment.

"Our new findings demonstrate that Diraq's silicon qubits can be fabricated using processes that are widely used in semiconductor foundries, meeting the threshold for fault tolerance in a way that is cost-effective and industry-compatible," Prof. Dzurak said.

Diraq and imec previously showed that qubits manufactured using CMOS processes - the same technology used to build everyday computer chips - could perform single-qubit operations with 99.9% accuracy. But more complex operations using two qubits that are critical to achieving utility scale had not yet been demonstrated.

"This latest achievement clears the way for the development of a fully fault-tolerant, functional quantum computer that is more cost effective than any other qubit platform," Prof. Dzurak said.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a major breakthrough in quantum computing technology, demonstrating that high-fidelity silicon-based quantum chips can be reliably mass-produced using existing semiconductor manufacturing processes. This achievement addresses a significant hurdle toward scalable, cost-effective utility-scale quantum computers, which have the potential to solve complex problems beyond current classical computers. The impact is broad and meaningful for the future of computing and technology.
articles.personality_title: Silicon quantum chips prove ready for real-world mass production
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Quantum computers use tiny units called qubits to process information much faster than regular computers. But making qubits accurate and reliable when produced in large numbers has been a big challenge.

**What happened** – Australian startup Diraq teamed up with the European institute imec to show that silicon-based quantum chips can be made in mass-production factories with over 99% accuracy. They proved these chips work just as well outside the lab, using established semiconductor factory methods.

**Impact** – This is important because it shows quantum chips can be built in large quantities without losing quality. Using silicon, the same material as in everyday computer chips, means these quantum processors could be made more cheaply and on a bigger scale. This brings quantum computers closer to solving problems that today’s best supercomputers cannot.

**What's next step** – The teams aim to build quantum processors with millions of these reliable qubits. Their next goal is to create fully fault-tolerant quantum computers that can run complex tasks commercially and cost-effectively.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Diraq’s silicon quantum chips have proven they can be mass-produced with high accuracy, moving quantum computing closer to practical use.

articles.title: The accidental discovery that forged the Iron Age
articles.summary: Ancient copper smelters may have accidentally set the stage for the Iron Age. At a 3,000-year-old workshop in Georgia, researchers discovered that metalworkers were using iron oxide not to smelt iron but to improve copper yields. This experimentation shows how curiosity with materials could have sparked one of history’s greatest technological leaps, turning iron from a rare celestial metal into the backbone of empires and industry.
articles.content:
Research from Cranfield University sheds new light onto the transition from the Bronze Age to the Iron Age, showing how experimentation with iron-rich rocks by copper smelters may have sparked the invention of iron.

The work reanalyzed metallurgical remains from a site in southern Georgia: a 3000-year-old smelting workshop called Kvemo Bolnisi. During the original analysis in the 1950s, piles of hematite (an iron oxide mineral) and slag (a waste product of the metal production) were found in the workshop. Finding those iron oxides, the original excavators thought the workshop was an early iron smelting site.

However, new research shows that those assumptions were wrong. Rather than iron, workers at Kvemo Bolnisi were smelting copper using iron oxide as a flux -- a substance added into the furnace to increase the resulting copper yield.

These discoveries give weight to a long-discussed theory that iron was invented by copper smelters. This evidence shows that ancient copper metalworkers experimented with iron-bearing materials in a metallurgical furnace, which was a crucial step towards iron smelting.

The importance of iron

While the Iron Age marked the beginnings of widespread iron production, the metal itself wasn't a new discovery. Iron artifacts have been found dating from the Bronze Age, most famously an iron dagger with a gold and rock crystal hilt from the tomb of Egyptian king Tutankhamun. But the earliest iron objects were forged from naturally occurring metallic iron found in meteorites, not extracted from iron ore through smelting. That rarity meant iron was, at that point in history, more valuable than gold.

The development of extractive iron metallurgy changed all this. Iron is one of the most abundant elements on Earth, even though naturally occurring iron metal is very rare. The ability to extract iron from iron ore and work it into useful materials such as tools or weapons is one of the defining technological transformations in human history. The transition into the Iron Age was far from instantaneous, but it gave rise to the iron-wielding armies of Assyria and Rome and later the railroads and steel-frame buildings of the industrial revolution.

Dr Nathaniel Erb-Satullo, Visiting Fellow in Archaeological Science at Cranfield University, said: "Iron is the world's quintessential industrial metal, but the lack of written records, iron's tendency to rust, and a lack of research on iron production sites has made the search for its origins challenging.

"That's what makes this site at Kvemo Bolnisi so exciting. It's evidence of intentional use of iron in the copper smelting process. That shows that these metalworkers understood iron oxide -- the geological compounds that would eventually be used as ore for iron smelting -- as a separate material and experimented with its properties within the furnace. Its use here suggests that this kind of experimentation by copper-workers was crucial to development of iron metallurgy.

"There's a beautiful symmetry in this kind of research, in that we can use the techniques of modern geology and materials science to get into the minds of ancient materials scientists. And we can do all this through the analysis of slag -- a mundane waste material that looks like lumps of funny-looking rock."

The research was supported by grants from the British Institute of Ankara, the Gerda Henkel Foundation, and the American Research Institute of the South Causcasus. The research paper Iron in copper metallurgy at the dawn of the Iron Age: Insights on iron invention from a mining and smelting site in the Caucasus is published in the Journal of Archaeological Science.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant archaeological and metallurgical discovery that sheds light on the origins of iron smelting, a major technological breakthrough that shaped human civilization. The research reveals how ancient copper smelters' experimentation with iron oxide led to the invention of iron metallurgy, a transformation with broad historical and technological impact. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a meaningful advancement in understanding a pivotal moment in human technological development.
articles.personality_title: Ancient copper workers’ experiments helped start the Iron Age
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Around 3,000 years ago, during the Bronze Age, people used mostly copper and bronze tools. Iron was very rare and valuable because it came from meteorites. The switch to making tools and weapons from iron marked the start of the Iron Age, a big change in human history.

**What happened** – Researchers studied an ancient copper smelting workshop in Georgia called Kvemo Bolnisi. They found that workers there used iron oxide, not to make iron, but to help produce more copper. This shows that these metalworkers were experimenting with iron materials in their furnaces, which may have led to the first ways of smelting iron.

**Impact** – This discovery explains how the knowledge to make iron might have started by accident during copper production. It helps us understand how humans moved from rare iron objects to widespread iron tools that shaped empires and industries. It also shows that ancient metalworkers were curious and skilled, trying new things with the materials they had.

**What's next step** – Scientists will likely study more ancient sites and materials to learn exactly how these early experiments developed into full iron smelting. This could reveal more about the spread of iron technology and how it changed societies around the world.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Ancient copper smelters’ clever use of iron oxide paved the way for the Iron Age and a major leap in human technology.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les expériences des anciens fondeurs de cuivre ont lancé l’âge du fer
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Il y a environ 3 000 ans, à l’époque du bronze, les gens utilisaient surtout des outils en cuivre et en bronze. Le fer était très rare et précieux car il venait des météorites. Le passage à la fabrication d’outils en fer a marqué le début de l’âge du fer, un grand changement dans l’histoire humaine.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs ont étudié un ancien atelier de fusion de cuivre en Géorgie appelé Kvemo Bolnisi. Ils ont découvert que les ouvriers utilisaient de l’oxyde de fer non pas pour fabriquer du fer, mais pour augmenter la production de cuivre. Cela montre que ces métallurgistes expérimentaient avec des matériaux ferreux dans leurs fours, ce qui pourrait avoir conduit aux premières méthodes de fusion du fer.

**Impact** – Cette découverte explique comment la connaissance de la fabrication du fer a pu commencer par hasard lors de la production de cuivre. Elle nous aide à comprendre comment les humains sont passés d’objets en fer rares à des outils en fer largement utilisés qui ont façonné des empires et des industries. Elle montre aussi que les anciens métallurgistes étaient curieux et compétents, essayant de nouvelles choses avec les matériaux à leur disposition.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont probablement étudier d’autres sites anciens et matériaux pour comprendre comment ces premières expériences ont évolué vers la fusion complète du fer. Cela pourrait révéler davantage sur la diffusion de la technologie du fer et son impact sur les sociétés dans le monde.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’utilisation ingénieuse de l’oxyde de fer par les anciens fondeurs de cuivre a ouvert la voie à l’âge du fer et à un grand bond technologique.
articles.personality_title_es: Los antiguos fundidores de cobre ayudaron a iniciar la Edad del Hierro
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Hace unos 3.000 años, durante la Edad del Bronce, la gente usaba principalmente herramientas de cobre y bronce. El hierro era muy raro y valioso porque provenía de meteoritos. El cambio a fabricar herramientas y armas de hierro marcó el comienzo de la Edad del Hierro, un gran cambio en la historia humana.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores estudiaron un antiguo taller de fundición de cobre en Georgia llamado Kvemo Bolnisi. Descubrieron que los trabajadores usaban óxido de hierro no para hacer hierro, sino para ayudar a producir más cobre. Esto muestra que estos metalúrgicos experimentaban con materiales de hierro en sus hornos, lo que pudo llevar a las primeras formas de fundición de hierro.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo explica cómo el conocimiento para fabricar hierro pudo comenzar por accidente durante la producción de cobre. Nos ayuda a entender cómo los humanos pasaron de objetos de hierro raros a herramientas de hierro comunes que moldearon imperios e industrias. También muestra que los antiguos metalúrgicos eran curiosos y hábiles, probando cosas nuevas con los materiales que tenían.

**Próximo paso** – Es probable que los científicos estudien más sitios y materiales antiguos para aprender cómo estos primeros experimentos se convirtieron en la fundición completa del hierro. Esto podría revelar más sobre la difusión de la tecnología del hierro y cómo cambió las sociedades en todo el mundo.

**Resumen en una frase** – El uso inteligente del óxido de hierro por parte de antiguos fundidores de cobre abrió el camino para la Edad del Hierro y un gran avance tecnológico.

articles.title: US serial killer case opens door to using cutting-edge DNA data in courts
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 25 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03102-8New York trial could set a legal precedent by admitting findings from whole-genome sequencing as evidence.
articles.content:
A crime laboratory officer removes material from the house of the prime suspect in the Gilgo Beach killings.Credit: Jeenah Moon/AP Photo/Alamy

A judge in New York rejected a request on 23 September to disqualify the use of cutting-edge DNA sequencing as evidence in a case against an alleged serial killer. The ruling paves the way for a type of DNA analysis known as whole-genome sequencing — used to decipher ancient DNA in fossilized remains, for example — to be admitted as evidence in US criminal trials.

“This is a big step forward for the use of DNA evidence, because it will allow comparisons and matches with evidence that was previously considered too minuscule, too old or too badly degraded to be considered useful,” says Nathan Lents, a biologist at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice in New York City. “You can bet that cold-case units all over the country are going back through their evidence lockers to see if there are samples that can now be tested with a reasonable chance of success.”

A technology matures

The Gilgo Beach killings were a series of murders that occurred in Suffolk County, New York, between 1993 and 2011. Many of the victims were sex workers, and the bodies of some of them were found near the eponymous beach. New York architect Rex Heuermann was charged with seven of the murders in 2023 and 2024 partially on the basis of hairs found on the victims.

In 2010, investigators concluded that there wasn’t enough genetic material in the hairs for conventional forensic technology to identify whose they were. But since then, genomic technology has matured at a fast pace.

Rex Heuermann appears in a New York court in 2023. Credit: James Carbone/AP Photo/Alamy

Forensic scientists still identify suspects from hair and other samples using the conventional polymerase chain reaction (PCR) method, which can amplify snippets of DNA called short tandem repeats (STRs). Today, however, scientists can also sequence whole genomes and look at single-letter variations in the DNA to zero in on a person of interest. This technology has the added benefit of being able to analyse severely degraded samples — from Neanderthal remains to hairs in the Gilgo Beach case. But it has typically been used only during investigations, and the results have not been widely presented as evidence before juries.

The controversial company using DNA to sketch the faces of criminals

The prosecution in the Gilgo Beach case contracted the company Astrea Forensics in Santa Cruz, California, to analyse the hairs found on the victims. Because they were rootless, they hadn’t yielded enough DNA for conventional STR profiling. (Rootless hairs are mostly made of keratin and don’t contain much genetic material, Lents says.)

But Astrea was able to sequence the small amount of genetic material in the hairs and then use statistical-analysis software to scan the DNA for single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) — single-letter differences in people’s genetic codes. Even in a degraded sample, whole-genome sequencing followed by this statistical analysis can spot thousands of SNPs: enough to pinpoint an individual’s unique pattern, Lents says.

Next, scientists at Astrea compared the SNP profiles they obtained with profiles stored in genealogy databases and looked for matches. People submit their DNA to genealogy services, such as 23andMe and Ancestry, and these companies return SNP profiles that people can then upload to websites such as GEDMatch to locate potential relatives. Users have the option to make the data available to forensic genealogists — and these data are what Astrea used to zero in on Heuermann and his family.

Setting precedent

The defence team in the Gilgo Beach case initially challenged the validity of Astrea’s DNA-analysis methods — which were developed by palaeogenomics researcher Richard ‘Ed’ Green at the University of California, Santa Cruz. (Green declined to comment for this article, given the ongoing prosecution.) The defence argued that the statistical methods used by Astrea were unique, and questioned whether they had been sufficiently validated.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant legal precedent allowing advanced whole-genome sequencing DNA evidence in criminal trials, enabling identification from previously unusable samples. This breakthrough has broad societal impact by potentially solving cold cases and improving justice delivery.
articles.personality_title: New DNA technology allowed in US court for first time in serial killer case
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In New York, a judge has allowed a new type of DNA testing called whole-genome sequencing to be used as evidence in a criminal trial. This technology reads a person’s entire genetic code and has mostly been used in science, like studying ancient fossils.

**What happened** – The case involves Rex Heuermann, accused of killing seven people in the Gilgo Beach murders. Investigators found tiny hairs on the victims that old DNA methods couldn’t analyze because the hairs didn’t have enough genetic material. A company named Astrea Forensics used whole-genome sequencing to study these hairs and matched the DNA to Heuermann and his family by comparing it to public genealogy databases.

**Impact** – This is the first time this advanced DNA method is accepted as evidence in a US court. It means that very old, tiny, or damaged DNA samples that were once useless can now help identify suspects. This could help solve many cold cases where evidence was previously too weak.

**What's next step** – Other crime units across the country may now look back at unsolved cases to test old evidence with whole-genome sequencing. The legal system will also watch how this new evidence is used and challenged in future trials to decide how widely it can be applied.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Whole-genome sequencing DNA evidence has opened a new path for solving crimes by allowing courts to use genetic clues from samples once thought unusable.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle technologie ADN autorisée pour la première fois dans un procès aux États-Unis
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – À New York, un juge a autorisé un nouveau type d’analyse ADN appelé séquençage complet du génome à être utilisé comme preuve lors d’un procès pénal. Cette technologie lit tout le code génétique d’une personne et était surtout utilisée en science, comme pour étudier des fossiles anciens.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – L’affaire concerne Rex Heuermann, accusé d’avoir tué sept personnes dans les meurtres de Gilgo Beach. Les enquêteurs ont trouvé de petits cheveux sur les victimes que les anciennes méthodes ADN ne pouvaient pas analyser car ils contenaient trop peu de matériel génétique. Une entreprise appelée Astrea Forensics a utilisé le séquençage complet du génome pour étudier ces cheveux et a retrouvé l’ADN de Heuermann et de sa famille en le comparant aux bases de données généalogiques publiques.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois que cette méthode ADN avancée est acceptée comme preuve dans un tribunal américain. Cela signifie que des échantillons ADN très anciens, petits ou abîmés, auparavant inutilisables, peuvent maintenant aider à identifier des suspects. Cela pourrait permettre de résoudre de nombreuses affaires non élucidées.

**Étape suivante** – D’autres unités criminelles à travers le pays pourraient maintenant revoir des affaires non résolues pour tester d’anciennes preuves avec le séquençage complet du génome. Le système judiciaire observera aussi comment ces nouvelles preuves sont utilisées et contestées dans les futurs procès pour décider de leur usage plus large.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le séquençage complet du génome ouvre une nouvelle voie pour résoudre des crimes en permettant aux tribunaux d’utiliser des indices génétiques issus d’échantillons auparavant inutilisables.
articles.personality_title_es: Nueva tecnología de ADN permitida por primera vez en un juicio en EE.UU.
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En Nueva York, un juez permitió usar un nuevo tipo de análisis de ADN llamado secuenciación del genoma completo como prueba en un juicio penal. Esta tecnología lee todo el código genético de una persona y se usaba principalmente en ciencia, por ejemplo para estudiar fósiles antiguos.

**Qué pasó** – El caso involucra a Rex Heuermann, acusado de matar a siete personas en los asesinatos de Gilgo Beach. Los investigadores encontraron pequeños cabellos en las víctimas que los métodos antiguos no podían analizar porque tenían muy poco material genético. Una empresa llamada Astrea Forensics usó la secuenciación del genoma completo para estudiar esos cabellos y comparó el ADN con bases de datos genealógicas públicas para identificar a Heuermann y su familia.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que este método avanzado de ADN se acepta como prueba en un tribunal de EE.UU. Esto significa que muestras de ADN muy antiguas, pequeñas o dañadas que antes no servían, ahora pueden ayudar a identificar sospechosos. Esto podría ayudar a resolver muchos casos sin resolver.

**Próximo paso** – Otras unidades policiales en el país podrían revisar casos antiguos para probar evidencias viejas usando secuenciación del genoma completo. El sistema legal también evaluará cómo se usa y cuestiona esta nueva evidencia en futuros juicios para decidir su uso generalizado.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La secuenciación del genoma completo abre una nueva forma de resolver crímenes al permitir que los tribunales usen pistas genéticas de muestras antes consideradas inútiles.
